results.title: Blocks (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: MacMillan Film Productions and G.A. Howe
results.brief_description: This film shows how constructive play with blocks of different shapes and sizes can be used to foster the basic perceptive skills and to develop logical thinking, concepts of height, eye-hand co-ordination, symmetry and balance.

results.title: Blocking and sampling
results.creator_credit: Peggy Girshman, Jill Singer, American Statistical Association, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Against all odds: inside statistics”.
When setting up an experiment one must consider if the subjects differ in any systematic way that may effect the results. Blocking is used when subjects share the same characteristics but when there may be some variability, as in agricultural experiments, such as the example shown, of testing new varieties of strawberries. A census counts everything but obviously has inherent difficulties which are illustrated. Sampling is a way of circumventing these difficulties and some of the problems of true representation are shown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peggy Girshman, Jill Singer, American Statistical Association, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP

constellations_other.name: Newsreel to nightly news
constellations_other.description: For decades, newsreel companies covered the news, providing weekly stories of current events, sport, and entertainment to audiences at the cinema, and establishing the format that would be taken up by television and the nightly news.

results.title: Blithe spirit
results.creator_credit: Anthony Havelock-Allan, Two Cities Films, Cineguild and David Lean
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Noel Coward. Charles, a celebrated novelist and his second wife, Ruth, invite a medium to dinner to aid Charles in writing a thriller about mediums. At the seance, unseen by others present, Charles’ first wife, Elvira, appears and although the medium and Ruth attempt to send Elvira back, she has devised a scheme to keep Charles with her forever. Stars Rex Harrison, Kay Hammond, Constance Cummings and Margaret Rutherford.

results.title: Bliss
results.creator_credit: Anthony Buckley, Window III, New South Wales Film Corporation and Ray Lawrence
results.brief_description: Bliss is the story of a man who so misunderstood the world that he almost got it right. The man is Harry Joy, he is happy, he has a successful business, a lovely wife and two loving children. When he dies, his life is ruined. He comes back to life and takes a good look at the world around him. His wife is sleeping with his partner, half of everything he eats causes cancer and an elephant sits on his car. No wonder Harry Joy believes that he has gone to hell. This film is based on the novel by Peter Carey. Cast includes Barry Otto, Lynette Curran, Helen Jones, Miles Buchanan and Gia Carides.

results.title: Blinky Bill production featurette
results.brief_description: Documentary capturing the production process behind the creation of a Blinky Bill animated film. Includes storyboard and cel animation, sound recording, filming live action footage, creating models, music composition and sound recording.Yoram Gross, John Palmer (writer), Frank Hammond (cinematographer), Ray Nowland (art director), Guy Gross (composer) and other crew are also featured discussing their work.

results.title: Blinky Bill (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Yoram Gross Films and Yoram Gross
results.brief_description: Blinky Bill the koala sets off to try and find his mother after their peaceful bush home is destroyed by loggers. He meets new friends and has many adventures along the way in this delightful animated film which is based on Dorothy Wall’s classic story.

results.title: Blinkity blank
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Norman McLaren and Tom Daly
results.brief_description: A film experiment by Norman McLaren in the use of intermittent animation and spasmodic imagery. McLaren makes play with the laws relating to persistence of vision and after image on the retina of the eye. By engraving non-representational visuals directly on black, emulsion-coated films in interrupted sequence, he achieves a ‘Now you see it, now you don’t effect. The music background is in the form of semi-free instrumental improvisation, with percussive effects added by synthetic sounds scratched directly on film. (Awards: London, Cannes, Edinburgh, Berlin, Los Angeles)
